page.title: 03Purley 50 Years Ago
page.content: Miss Routledge came to Purley in 1932 and started her school.There were very few houses in Old Lodge Lane, just two farms and a large stone house in Haydn Avenue beloging to the local landowner, Mr Betts, an eccentric kind man. The Downs were covered with wild flowers, particularly orchids, bluebells and lots of wild strawberries. Soon after she came a local bus service started up the lane, called the Flying Flea. There were no bus stops and the driver put people down outside their own front door. Purley had lots of small grocery shops. It was where the trams turned round. The children from Reedham Orphanage used to watch the Queen's train going to the Derby at Epsom.
